title: Fitting Hearing Aids to a Patient with Mild Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I've noticed greater difficulty with my hearing recently, especially in background noise. I find myself asking people to repeat themselves more often, and I think it might be time to consider hearing aids.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual; patient returned for an annual evaluation after noticing changes.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; slight decrease in thresholds (15 dB) noted in the right ear at 4000 and 6000 Hz compared to previous evaluation.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus (more noticeable in the right ear); occasional dizziness/vertigo (attributed to medication).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty understanding speech in noise; asking people to repeat often.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is interested in how hearing aids may assist her; motivated to consider amplification.

history.present_illness: Patient returned for annual evaluation. Previously noted difficulty in noise but did not feel ready for intervention. Now reports increased difficulty and is ready to consider options.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia or aural fullness. Occasional dizziness/vertigo likely medication-related.
history.medical_psych_history: Dizziness discussed with primary care physician.
history.prior_management: Annual monitoring; previous discussion of hearing aids.
history.patient_goals: To improve hearing, specifically in noise.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight SNHL 250-3000 Hz, sloping to mild at 4000 Hz, slight at 6000 Hz, mild at 8000 Hz. Left ear: Normal to slight SNHL 250-2000 Hz, sloping to mild 3000-4000 Hz, moderate at 6000 Hz, mild at 8000 Hz.

numeric_results.RE_Thresholds: 20-25 dB low/mid freqs, dip to 35 dB at 4k, 35 dB at 8k
numeric_results.LE_Thresholds: 15-20 dB low freqs, dip to 35 dB at 4k, 50 dB at 6k

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition thresholds (SRT) show slight loss consistent with pure tones. Word recognition scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, static compliance, and middle ear pressure bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present and normal for ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500 to 4,000 Hz. Decay negative.

history.present_illness: Patient returned for hearing aid fitting.
history.prior_management: Hearing aids ordered at previous visit.

tests.name: Real-Ear Measurements (REM)
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids verified to NAL-NL1 targets. Slight adjustments made for comfort and sound quality.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN testing reveals a severe signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) loss unaided.

tests.name: Washington University Hearing Aid Self-Assessment Scale
tests.key_findings: Hearing difficulty present in most situations (marked as 'Sometimes').

treatments.name: Hearing Aid Fitting
treatments.details: Bilateral open-fit receiver-in-the-canal (RIC) hearing aids with open domes. Made-for-iPhone. Programmed to NAL-NL1.

history.present_illness: 2-week follow-up. Patient reports doing well and is satisfied. Significantly better in noise.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement noted with hearing aids.

tests.name: Washington University Hearing Aid Self-Assessment Scale
tests.key_findings: Improvement in all categories (marked as 'Rarely' or 'Never' for difficulty).

encounters.outcome: Patient satisfied with hearing aids. No further intervention warranted.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, generally mild, sloping sensorineural hearing loss. While word recognition in quiet is excellent (96-100%), she demonstrates a severe deficit in signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) loss (~18 dB) on the QuickSIN test, which correlates with her chief complaint of difficulty hearing in noise. Middle ear function is normal.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a mild permanent hearing loss in both ears, which has changed slightly since your last visit.
While you understand speech very well in quiet environments, the testing confirms you have significant difficulty separating speech from background noise.
Hearing aids can provide benefit, but given the severity of the difficulty in noise, we may also need to discuss additional accessories (like remote microphones) for noisy situations.
Tinnitus is often associated with hearing loss; amplification often helps reduce the perception of tinnitus.
notes_for_actor: You are motivated to try hearing aids now, unlike your last visit.
You are specifically frustrated by background noise situations.
You have ringing in your ears (tinnitus), worse on the right side.
